metadata.titleEn: Indian Ocean Tropical cyclone best track and satellite-based precipitation and convection datasets（1978-2019；2000-2019）
metadata.description:
The accuracy of tropical cyclone (tropical storm) track forecasting improved by nearly 50% for lead times of 24–72 h since 1990s. Over the same period forecasting of tropical cyclone intensity showed only limited improvement. Given the limited prediction skill of models of tropical cyclone intensity based on environmental properties, there have been a wealth of studies of the role of internal dynamical processes of tropical cyclones, which are largely linked to precipitation properties and convective processes. The release of latent heat by convection in the inner core of a tropical cyclone is considered crucial to tropical cyclone intensification. 16-year satellite-based precipitation, and clouds top infrared brightness temperature were used to explore the relationship between precipitation, convective cloud, and tropical cyclone intensity change.  The 6-hourly TC centers were linearly interpolated to give the hourly and half hourly tropical cyclone center positions, to match the temporal resolution of the precipitation and clouds top infrared brightness temperature.
More precipitation is found as storms intensify, while tropical cyclone 24 h future intensity change is closely connected with very deep convective clouds with IR BT < 208 K. Intensifying tropical cyclones follow the occurrence of colder clouds with IR BT < 208 K with greater areal extents. As an indicator of very deep convective clouds, IR BT < 208 K is suggested to be a good predictor of tropical cyclone intensity change（Ruan&Wu，2018，GRL）. The properties of the satellite-based precipitation, and clouds top infrared brightness temperature are therefore suggested to be important measurements to study tropical cyclone intensity, intensity change and their underlying mechanisms. The high resolution of the satellite-based precipitation (3h), and cloud top infrared brightness temperature (half hour) datasets also makes them possible to be used to study tropical cyclone variability associated with diurnal cycle.
metadata.instructions:
The data is in NC format, and each tropical cyclone is a file. The tropical cyclones in each year are listed in order of occurrence, such as 2001_ 2. NC is the data related to the second tropical cyclone in the ocean basin in 2001. Each document includes the basic information of tropical cyclone, such as longitude and latitude, time, maximum sustained wind speed and name of tropical cyclone, spatial distribution of infrared cloud top brightness temperature and rainfall within 500km of tropical cyclone center, as well as longitude and latitude distribution of corresponding space.
In order to match the satellite data, the location of the track center is interpolated to every hour. The rainfall data corresponding to tropical cyclones is calculated based on TRMM satellite observation and cloud top brightness temperature data corresponding to tropical cyclones are calculated based on multi-source orbit determination infrared satellite.
It is divided into two folders according to the North Indian Ocean and the South Indian Ocean. Each variable is described in the following table.
                                                             Time resolution   Description
lat   Latitude of tropical cyclone center     per hour       Best path raw data time resolution is 6h, which is 0, 6, 12 and 18 h (UTC) respectively, and is linearly interpolated to every hour
lon  Longitude of tropical cyclone center  per hour      The same as above
vmax maximum sustained wind speed      per hour      The same as above
time  Tropical cyclone time                        per hour      Best path time resolution is 6h, which is 0,6,12,18h (UTC) Julian day
data00 Infrared brightness temperature    per hour      The spatial distribution within 500km of the tropical cyclone center at  the hour (UTC) 
data30 Infrared brightness temperature    per hour      The spatial distribution within 500km of the tropical cyclone center at  the half hour (UTC) 
lonm_bt The longitude distribution of infrared brightness temperature  per hour  The corresponding longitude distribution of data00 and data30

lonm_pre   Longitude distribution of precipitation every 3 hours  Longitude distribution of precip 
latm_pre    Latitude distribution of precipitation every 3 hours  Latitude distribution of precip

background: The accuracy of tropical cyclone (TC) track forecasting improved by nearly 50% for lead times of 24–72 h between 1990 and 2008; over the same period forecasting of TC intensity showed only limited improvement. Although it is well known that TC intensification occurs more readily under conditions of higher sea surface temperature, lower vertical wind shear, and higher low troposphere moisture, and these environments are critically important to the prediction of TC intensity change in general and more specifically rapid intensification (RI), studies have shown that these environmental conditions alone are not sufficient to explain changes in TC intensity. Given the limited prediction skill of models of TC intensity based on environmental properties, there have been a wealth of studies of the role of internal dynamical processes of TCs, which are largely linked to precipitation properties and convective processes. The release of latent heat by convection in the inner core of a TC is considered crucial to TC intensification. Through analysis of an 11 year Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission (TRMM) precipitation data set, Jiang (2012) found that extremely intense convection in the inner core increases the possibility of RI, but the difference is not substantial. Using the same data set, Jiang and Ramirez (2013) found that rapidly intensifying TCs are associated with a large area of rainfall with heavy rain in the inner core. By compositing 22 year passive microwave satellite overpasses, Harnos and Nesbitt (2011) detected a convective ring forming 6 h before the onset of RI. Using a 14 year TRMM precipitation radar (PR) data set, Tao and Jiang (2015) found that RI is more likely to be caused by shallow-moderate precipitation, while moderate to very deep convection observed during an RI is more likely to be a response. With two more years of TRMM PR data, Tao et al. (2017) claimed that RI follows significant increases in the occurrence and coverage of stratiform rain, thus stressing the importance of this type of rainfall. In a comparison with TCs with slow intensification rates, Alvey et al. (2015) used 15 year multisatellite passive microwave data to show that storms with higher intensification rates have more symmetric distributions and a larger overall coverage of precipitation prior to the onset of intensification. Satellite-based statistical studies can be used to draw more robust conclusions through analysis of more data sets. However, consensus on the importance of different properties of convection on TC intensity change, especially RI, has not yet been reached despite the extensive use of satellite data by the authors of these cited works. The extent to which convection is a precursor, or simply a reflection of other processes occurring during RI, is also unclear. Studying the diurnal variations in TC convective cloud systems for the period 2000–2013, Wu and Ruan (2016) found that clouds with IR BT< 208 K have a maximum coverage in the morning, and clouds with 208 K< IR BT < 240 K have a maximum coverage in the afternoon. An IR BT of 208 K was chosen as a threshold to identify very deep convection within IR data. Clouds with IR BT < 208 K and 208 K< IR BT < 240 K are termed “very cold deep convective clouds” and “cold high clouds,” respectively, influenced by different diurnal cycles. Different diurnal cycles and different underlying physical mechanisms associated with these two types of TC clouds suggest that they might play different roles in TC intensity change.
research objective: In this paper, satellite-based precipitation, clouds with infrared (IR) brightness temperature (BT), and tropical cyclone (TC) data from 2000 to 2015 are used to explore the relationship between precipitation, convective cloud, and TC intensity change in the Western North Pacific Ocean. In this paper we use 16 year (2000–2015) precipitation data, IR BT data, and TC information to examine the relationships between precipitation, very deep convective clouds, high clouds, and TC intensity changes.
challenges: Although guidance on the intensity of TCs has seen significant improvements, forecasting the intensification of TCs is still a real challenge. Studies have shown that these environmental conditions alone are not sufficient to explain changes in TC intensity. Given the limited prediction skill of models of TC intensity based on environmental properties, there have been a wealth of studies of the role of internal dynamical processes of TCs, which are largely linked to precipitation properties and convective processes. Satellite-based statistical studies can be used to draw more robust conclusions through analysis of more data sets. However, consensus on the importance of different properties of convection on TC intensity change, especially RI, has not yet been reached despite the extensive use of satellite data by the authors of these cited works. The extent to which convection is a precursor, or simply a reflection of other processes occurring during RI, is also unclear.
methods: Best track data were provided by the United States Navy Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The 6-hourly records of the position of the TC center, the intensity of the TC, and other important parameters were included in the best-track data, typically at 0000, 0600, 1200, and 1800 UTC. The 6-hourly TC centers were linearly interpolated to give the 3-hourly and hourly TC center positions, to match the temporal resolution of the precipitation and IR BT data, respectively. A total of 437 storms in the western North Pacific were analyzed for the period 2000–2015. The precipitation data used in this paper are rates of rainfall from the NASA TRMM Multisatellite Precipitation Analysis (TMPA). The TMPA operational product used in this paper is 3B42 (version 7) and has a horizontal resolution of 0.25° × 0.25° between 50°N and 50°S, with a temporal resolution of 3 h. Half-hourly global merged IR BT data were obtained from the United States National Centers for Environmental Prediction Climate Prediction Center. The IR BT data have a pixel size of 4 km by 4 km between 60°N and 60°S. The half-hourly IR BT data were averaged to hourly data to fill gaps in the data. All precipitation and IR BT images were evaluated in terms of TC intensity (maximum sustained wind) and 24 h future intensity changes. All satellite images must show the best-track position 300 km or more away from land to remove any influence from it. The wind fields were obtained from the 0.75° resolution European Centre for Medium Range Weather Forecasts interim reanalysis data set. In this paper, each image is evaluated using wind shear relative coordinates, with wind shear defined as the difference between 850 and 200 hPa winds averaged at a radius of 200–800 km from the TC center. The 6-hourly wind shear data were linearly interpolated to give hourly data to match the temporal resolution of IR BT data.
dataset: The 6-hourly records of the position of the TC center, the intensity of the TC, and other important parameters were included in the best-track data, typically at 0000, 0600, 1200, and 1800 UTC. A total of 437 storms in the western North Pacific were analyzed for the period 2000–2015. The precipitation data used in this paper are rates of rainfall from the NASA TRMM Multisatellite Precipitation Analysis (TMPA). The TMPA operational product used in this paper is 3B42 (version 7) and has a horizontal resolution of 0.25° × 0.25° between 50°N and 50°S, with a temporal resolution of 3 h. Half-hourly global merged IR BT data were obtained from the United States National Centers for Environmental Prediction Climate Prediction Center. The IR BT data have a pixel size of 4 km by 4 km between 60°N and 60°S.
findings: More precipitation and colder clouds with 208 K< IR BT< 240 K are found as storms intensify, while TC 24 h future intensity change is closely connected with very deep convective clouds with IR BT< 208 K. Intensifying TCs follow the occurrence of colder clouds with IR BT< 208 K with greater areal extents. As an indicator of very deep convective clouds, IR BT< 208 K is suggested to be a good predictor of TC intensity change. Based upon the 16 year analysis in the western North Pacific, TCs under the conditions that the mean temperature of very deep convective clouds is less than 201 K, and the coverage of this type of clouds is more than 27.4% within a radius of 300 km of the TC center, will more likely undergo rapid intensification after 24 h.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to match satellite observations with tropical cyclone best-track data in terms of time and space resolution?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involved in matching satellite observations with tropical cyclone best-track data includes spatial and temporal matching of original best-track data with satellite-derived precipitation and convective data. This includes matching positions, aligning time and space resolutions, and using linear interpolation to interpolate the track center position to hourly intervals.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using satellite data for analyzing tropical cyclone intensity changes?
Example.Answer: A challenge in using satellite data for analyzing tropical cyclone intensity changes is the limited prediction skill of models based on environmental properties alone, which has led to numerous studies on the role of internal dynamical processes linked to precipitation and convective processes. Despite extensive use of satellite data, consensus on the importance of different convection properties on intensity change, especially rapid intensification, remains unclear.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate an example of a dataset that provides insights into the relationship between tropical cyclone precipitation and intensity changes?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that provides insights into the relationship between tropical cyclone precipitation and intensity changes is the TRMM Multisatellite Precipitation Analysis (TMPA), which offers rainfall rates with a horizontal resolution of 0.25° × 0.25° and a temporal resolution of 3 hours. This dataset was used to analyze 437 storms in the western North Pacific from 2000 to 2015, focusing on the connection between precipitation, convective cloud features, and tropical cyclone intensity changes.

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'best track data' in the context of tropical cyclone research?
Definition.Answer: Best track data refers to the 6-hourly records of the position of the tropical cyclone center, the intensity of the cyclone, and other important parameters. These data are typically provided by sources like the United States Navy Joint Typhoon Warning Center and include information at specific times, such as 0000, 0600, 1200, and 1800 UTC.

Definition.Question: How is 'infrared brightness temperature' used in studying tropical cyclones?
Definition.Answer: Infrared brightness temperature (IR BT) is used to analyze cloud characteristics in tropical cyclones. It is measured using satellite data with a spatial resolution of 4 km, and helps identify features like very deep convective clouds based on temperature thresholds, such as IR BT < 208 K. This information is crucial for understanding changes in cyclone intensity.

Definition.Question: What is the role of 'latent heat release' in the context of tropical cyclone intensification?
Definition.Answer: Latent heat release by convection in the inner core of a tropical cyclone is considered a crucial process for cyclone intensification. It is linked to the precipitation and convective processes within the cyclone, where the release of latent heat contributes to the strengthening of the cyclone.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for tropical cyclone intensity forecasting in the Western North Pacific compare to those used in the Indian Ocean with respect to temporal resolution and data sources?
Comparison.Answer: In the Western North Pacific, data collection involves 6-hourly best-track data provided by the United States Navy Joint Typhoon Warning Center, with linear interpolation to achieve a 3-hourly and hourly temporal resolution for precipitation and infrared brightness temperature (IR BT) data. Precipitation data are sourced from the NASA TRMM Multisatellite Precipitation Analysis, and IR BT data from the United States National Centers for Environmental Prediction Climate Prediction Center. In contrast, the Indian Ocean data collection uses satellite observations to match best-track data within a 500-km radius, utilizing TRMM satellite for precipitation and multiple orbiting infrared satellites for cloud top brightness temperature, achieving a 3-hour temporal resolution for precipitation and half-hour for cloud top temperatures.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges are associated with using satellite data to predict tropical cyclone intensity changes, and how might researchers address these challenges?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges associated with using satellite data to predict tropical cyclone intensity changes include the limited prediction skill of models based on environmental properties and the difficulty in reaching a consensus on the importance of different convective properties. Researchers can address these challenges by employing satellite-based statistical studies to analyze more data sets, exploring the diurnal variations in convective cloud systems, and refining the understanding of how different types of clouds and precipitation influence cyclone intensity changes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in improving the prediction skill of tropical cyclone intensity using environmental properties?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Studies have shown that environmental conditions such as higher sea surface temperature, lower vertical wind shear, and higher low troposphere moisture are important but not sufficient to fully explain changes in tropical cyclone intensity. The limited prediction skill of models based solely on these environmental properties has led to further exploration of internal dynamical processes linked to precipitation properties and convective processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it difficult to reach a consensus on the role of different convective properties on tropical cyclone intensity change?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Despite extensive use of satellite data, there is no clear consensus on how different properties of convection impact tropical cyclone intensity change, especially rapid intensification. The extent to which convection is a precursor or merely a reflection of other processes occurring during rapid intensification remains unclear.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the difficulty in forecasting the intensification of tropical cyclones despite improvements in guidance on their intensity?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The forecasting of tropical cyclone intensification remains challenging because environmental conditions alone are not sufficient to explain intensity changes. The internal dynamical processes of tropical cyclones, largely linked to precipitation and convective processes, have been studied extensively, yet a clear understanding of their roles and mechanisms is still lacking.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes can be expected if satellite data is integrated with best track data to enhance the prediction of tropical cyclone intensity changes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating satellite data with best track data can lead to a better understanding of the relationship between precipitation, convective cloud characteristics, and tropical cyclone intensity changes. This approach helps to identify patterns such as the presence of very deep convective clouds, which can serve as indicators of potential rapid intensification of tropical cyclones.

Causal Consequence.Question: What results might be observed by using a dynamic extraction method for matching tropical cyclone paths with satellite data within a 500 km radius?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a dynamic extraction method allows for the accurate assessment of rainfall and cloud characteristics surrounding tropical cyclones. This method can reveal the influence of convective processes on cyclone intensity, indicating that larger areas of heavy rainfall and specific cloud patterns are associated with stronger cyclones and potential rapid intensification.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind integrating satellite-based precipitation and infrared brightness temperature data with tropical cyclone path data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration aims to explore the relationship between precipitation, convective cloud features, and tropical cyclone intensity changes, with a focus on understanding how these variables interact and contribute to the intensity and rapid intensification of cyclones.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives drive the analysis of deep convective cloud patterns in predicting tropical cyclone intensity changes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The analysis of deep convective cloud patterns aims to identify potential predictors for tropical cyclone intensity changes, particularly rapid intensification. By understanding the role and timing of these cloud features, researchers hope to improve forecasting models and provide more reliable predictions of cyclone behavior.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in matching tropical cyclone best track data with satellite precipitation and convective data to study the relationship with cyclone intensity changes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves spatially and temporally matching the original best track data of tropical cyclones with satellite precipitation and convective data. This includes aligning the positions and matching the temporal and spatial resolutions. Linear interpolation is used to interpolate the track center positions to an hourly basis. Rainfall data is calculated based on TRMM satellite observations, and cloud-top brightness temperature data is derived from multi-source geostationary satellites. Data within a 500 km radius of the cyclone center is dynamically extracted and calculated to obtain 3-hourly resolution precipitation and convective data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approach is used to ensure the quality and accuracy of the matched data from different sources when studying tropical cyclone intensity and related convective processes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The approach involves carefully matching data from different sources, such as best track data and satellite observations, ensuring that the temporal and spatial resolutions are compatible. Linear interpolation is applied to align the temporal resolutions of the datasets, and the data matching accounts for position and spatial resolution differences. The matched data is evaluated for quality by ensuring it aligns with known cyclone paths and characteristics, and any discrepancies are addressed through careful data preprocessing and validation.

Enablement.Question: What satellite technologies enable the collection of high-resolution precipitation and infrared brightness temperature data for tropical cyclone analysis?
Enablement.Answer: The use of NASA TRMM Multisatellite Precipitation Analysis (TMPA) and multi-source geostationary infrared satellites, such as those providing IR brightness temperature data, enables the collection of high-resolution precipitation and infrared brightness temperature data. These technologies allow for temporal resolutions of 3 hours and half-hourly data that can be averaged to hourly, with spatial resolutions of 0.25° for precipitation and 4 km for infrared data, respectively.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the assessment of diurnal variations in convective cloud systems associated with tropical cyclones?
Enablement.Answer: The assessment of diurnal variations in convective cloud systems is enabled by using satellite-based infrared brightness temperature data, which have a high temporal resolution of half-hourly observations. This allows researchers to identify and analyze the diurnal cycles of very cold deep convective clouds and cold high clouds, using thresholds such as an IR BT of 208 K to differentiate between these cloud types. The temporal resolution provides the detail needed to observe changes throughout the day, contributing to the understanding of their roles in tropical cyclone intensity change.

Expectation.Question: Why might the prediction models of tropical cyclone intensity based on environmental properties show limited prediction skill, despite improvements in data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: Although environmental conditions such as sea surface temperature and wind shear are important, they are not sufficient to explain changes in TC intensity. Internal dynamical processes, linked to precipitation properties and convective processes, play a crucial role that is not fully captured by environmental data alone.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of satellite-based statistical studies not have reached a consensus on the importance of different convection properties on tropical cyclone intensity change?
Expectation.Answer: The extensive use of satellite data has not led to a consensus because the role of convection as a precursor or a reflection of other processes during rapid intensification remains unclear. Different studies emphasize various aspects such as shallow-moderate precipitation or very deep convection, indicating complexity and variability in these processes.

Expectation.Question: Why do certain convective cloud characteristics, such as very deep convection, precede changes in tropical cyclone intensity, and how might this influence data collection strategies?
Expectation.Answer: Very deep convective clouds with IR BT < 208 K have been shown to precede TC intensity changes, suggesting they are important indicators. This influences data collection strategies by highlighting the need for precise temporal and spatial resolution in capturing convective cloud dynamics to predict intensity changes effectively.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the main challenges faced when integrating multiple satellite datasets for tropical cyclone research?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating multiple satellite datasets for tropical cyclone research presents challenges such as ensuring spatial and temporal matching of data from different sources, maintaining consistency in resolution and coverage, and dealing with potential data gaps. These challenges must be carefully managed to ensure that the integrated datasets provide an accurate and comprehensive view of the processes influencing tropical cyclone behavior.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the potential for expanding these datasets to improve our understanding of rapid intensification of tropical cyclones?
Judgmental.Answer: There is significant potential for expanding these datasets to enhance our understanding of rapid intensification of tropical cyclones. By increasing the temporal resolution and incorporating additional variables such as wind shear and sea surface temperature, researchers can gain a more comprehensive view of the factors contributing to rapid intensification. Additionally, the use of newer satellite technologies and increased computational power can lead to more detailed and accurate models.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how data collection methods can address the challenges of predicting tropical cyclone intensity changes effectively.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection methods in this domain often involve the integration of satellite-based precipitation and infrared brightness temperature data with best-track data of tropical cyclones. The challenges in predicting intensity changes are addressed by analyzing the internal dynamical processes of tropical cyclones, which are linked to precipitation properties and convective processes. Satellite-based statistical studies can provide more robust conclusions through the analysis of multiple datasets, though consensus on the importance of different convection properties remains unresolved.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the coverage and intensity of convective clouds are evaluated as indicators for tropical cyclone intensity changes.
Assertion.Answer: The evaluation of convective cloud coverage and intensity as indicators for tropical cyclone intensity changes involves analyzing infrared brightness temperature data. Clouds with IR BT below 208 K are considered very deep convective clouds and are used as predictors of intensity change. The analysis considers both the areal extent and the mean temperature of these clouds within a specified radius of the cyclone center to predict rapid intensification, providing an insight into the role of deep convection in cyclone dynamics.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the challenges encountered in forecasting tropical cyclone intensity changes despite advancements in track prediction.
Request/Directive.Answer: Although tropical cyclone track forecasting accuracy improved significantly between 1990 and 2008, the forecasting of intensity showed limited improvement. While environmental factors like sea surface temperature and wind shear are known to be important, they are insufficient to fully explain intensity changes. The complex role of internal dynamical processes, such as precipitation properties and convective processes, remains a challenge. Despite extensive use of satellite data, a consensus on the role of convection in intensity change, especially rapid intensification, has not yet been reached.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that can be used to study the relationship between tropical cyclone intensity changes and convective characteristics.
Request/Directive.Answer: Datasets such as the NASA TRMM Multisatellite Precipitation Analysis (TMPA) and global merged infrared brightness temperature data from the United States National Centers for Environmental Prediction Climate Prediction Center can be used. The TMPA operational product 3B42, version 7, provides rainfall rates with a horizontal resolution of 0.25° × 0.25° and a temporal resolution of 3 hours. Half-hourly infrared brightness temperature data have a pixel size of 4 km by 4 km, averaged to hourly data to study tropical cyclone intensity changes.
